comment.author: 48368774@N08
comment._content: It is interesiting to see that the lances are leaning against the scenic background, so is this taken in a studio or has a backdrop been set-up outside?

comment.author: 48586915@N03
comment._content: is this a fake scene?

comment.author: 13327104@N00
comment._content: Pretty sure that's not a back-drop.  Those are flag poles and the flags are flapping in the wind.  With the long exposure they slightly disappear, and that darker flag looks like a shadow when it's not.

comment.author: 48368774@N08
comment._content: It would be interesting to know  what the George Eastman House staff think. Even in an enlargement the flagpole appears to be leaning against the horizon line.  Many photographers of the era did set-ups, Curtis was well known for it.  Doesn't mean it is a fake.

comment.author: 9380710@N04
comment._content: I don't think it is a fake. What you are mistaking as a shadow is actually a ghosting of the flag from movement in the wind during the long exposure required.

comment.author: 8293323@N07
comment._content:
congratulations for your Atget´s albun...
Great collection...

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content:
This is obviously a backdrop that was set up outside.  That accounts for both the flag flapping in the wind and also for the end of the pole up against the backdrop.

The photographer's shadow is clearly seen at bottom left.  This would be from the sun at his back.  You would not see his shadow had this been shot in a studio.  Also, you can see the edge of what is probably a large canvas tarp in the lower right corner.

The real question is, why would anyone go through the bother using a backdrop outdoors?

comment.author: 9380710@N04
comment._content: It isn't obvious that it is a backdrop. There is no indication that the flag pole is up against a backdrop. What you are interpreting as the edge of the canvas backdrop in the lower right corner is a dark area of the image that was protected from fading and a crease in the image, or more likely another shadow the photographer didn't account for. If it was a canvas backdrop and that corner was the edge they would have had to gone to great lengths to cut out the canvas around the rocks. The shadow behind the flagpole that looks like a shadow on a backdrop is actually the ghosting of the moving flag during the long exposure. It isn't a lance leaning against the backdrop. Other things to consider is why would they do it and the backdrop would have had to been enormous. The Indian in front would have probably been 5.5 feet tall and the Indian in the rear is a good foot higher than him so lets say the height of the people posing is about 7 feet so I would guess that the backdrop would have had to been at least 40 feet tall to cover the area and probably at least 60 feet wide.

comment.author: 46135464@N00
comment._content: wowow!! indian cherroke wow tipis

comment.author: 48368774@N08
comment._content: Tipis? They look more like army tents, but who knows what type of tents they really are, or their pupose and what do Cherokees have to do with the photo?

comment.author: 7167652@N06
comment._content: I tend to agree that this photograph was not taken in front of a backdrop.  The flag poles do appear to be resting against something but it is just an illusion caused by the flags blowing in the wind.

comment.author: 48368774@N08
comment._content: Since I started all this, Thank You to George Eastman House for offering an opinion. The optics puzzled me, which is why I made the comment.

comment.author: 41807318@N06
comment._content: Looks like the background is a typical basin and range landscape in Nevada. The flags and poles are propped up behind them, and the flags are moving in the wind -- one so much it's barely visible in the photo. The tents are U.S. Army tents. There is a shallow range of focus, maybe because the photographer wanted to decrease the exposure time -- which still was a long time given the old emulsion. The Shoshones became famous scouts for the U.S. Army in the West -- they were excellent horsemen and worked well in the cavalries. Usually, there was an officer in charge of these scouts, in this case Captain Buck. Shoshone scouts went on to fight in the famous Plains Indian wars against the Sioux and Cheyenne. A good book to read about this is On The Border With Crook by Captain John G. Bourke.

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: I am changing my mind about the flagpole on the left and now agree that what appears to be a shadow there is the blur of the flag.  Also, it would make no sense to drag around a huge backdrop, especially one that has a a horizon that is not level.

comment.author: 27906564@N07
comment._content: This is one of the most interesting discussions I've happened upon on Flickr.  The image does create an optical illusion of having a back drop outdoors with the unusual fading perspective of flag and pole.  I suppose we are meant to give it an extra moment of consideration that we would not have done under normal circumstance; perhaps the people in the images want us to reflect on the portrait.

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: BDC, if you want to read a really interesting discussion on Flickr, read this www.flickr.com/photos/uscgd8/4551846015/

comment.author: 18317418@N00
comment._content: It does appear that the ground coverage blends in 'underneath' and is still visible under whatever type of tarp may have been used. It's also interesting that written in very small letters in the bottom border is 'No". Maybe the intent was to have that blunder edited out as well as the area in the middle, along the bottom of the image, where the edge of a folded covering is also visible. That would be an easy fix today with Photo Shop huh?

comment.author: 8613643@N07
comment._content: What an exquisite shot !!!

comment.author: 48368774@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/a1studiophotography] 
Dear A1 Studio Photography... since I started this thread; I was not attempting to discredit the photo, I was making an observation, which through the postings on this thread, I have understood my mistake, it is not a shadow against a backdrop but a ghosting of a fluttering flag, during a long exposure. As for expert comments, maybe you didn't notice that The George Eastman House has made a comment here on this photograpgh which is in their collection. I thank them for that and for the discussion that took place here.
I do object to your inference that Flickr users could not be qualified to make comments. So you know everyone's background, experience and education? I was not being pretentious, I was making an observation, which is not out of line. That is the wonderful and also qestionable thing about photographs past and present, they are not always what they appear to be.
If you are familiar with the photographs of the Canadian photographer William Notman, who was photographing in the late 1800s, you will know that it is possible to take "outdoor" photographs in a studio. He made wonderful photos, portraits of people in wintery scenes that were studio set-ups with backdrops, fake snow. etc. His intention was to chronicle life in Canada. My point being that my initial question was based on a possibility that there might be a backdrop.

comment.author: 30355535@N04
comment._content:
Hmm... Appreciated. And thank you for the direct and to the point intervention.
Also, I admit to human error on my part. And I do apologise for my apparent poor and shallow choice of words, in some case, on my comment. I mean, as for "Flickr user" so called individuals, well... certainly not addressing "Historians" in this case, nor "Experts".
Such would hardly ever deliver comments based on assumptions made from(in this case) digital copies. 
I do also apologise for the accusation of a "mistaken and pretentious" comment I made.
I realise that no harm was made intended and that this a "friendly" and positive thing we are doing here on Flickr, also very helpful and appreciated world wide.
I must say though, the disparaging comments made to and about A1StudioPhotography are but a taste of how, at times we may all, individuals and organisations alike, find ourselves caught by emotions in our actions. So to let clear of doubt, yes I did read the comments as we do, and it was in fact what inspired my critic except this time was a critic to us, not the photo. But it was only critique nothing more. Meant of course to inspire reflection and hopefully, growth for us as critics... sorry. 
Guys please accept my sincere apologies, I meant no harm.
Thank you all for your time and to George Eastman house.


 A1.

comment.author: 91886123@N05
comment._content: Captain Buck was a leader of the White Knife Shoshone. He signed the 1863 Ruby Valley Treaty.
